headline: Trump continues to cry "obvious fraud" in Georgia  even after losing candidates he endorsed concede
author: Jon Skolnik
sentences: More than one week after Perdue conceded on election night, the former president revised his fraud conspiracies in an email sent out by his "Save America" PAC, which linked to an article posted by former Newsmax correspondent Emerald Robinson.

Last month, Trump-backed secretary of state candidate Rep. Jodi Hice, R-Ga., lost to incumbent Brad Raffensperger, who famously rejected the former president's request to "find" enough votes to overturn the election in Trump's favor.

RELATED: Georgia GOP outraged Trump turned against Brian Kemp: 'I am just so mad  beyond words"
There is no evidence that Georgia's gubernatorial primary was impacted by fraud.
"Dear Christians: the vaccines contain a bioluminescent marker called LUCIFERASE so that you can be tracked," she wrote at the time in a since-deleted Twitter post.
Further, while a 52% margin of victory might be relatively large for most elections, it is not unprecedented, as journalist Steven Fowler explained over Twitter.
Donald Trump, who has backed former Sen. David Perdue, R-Ga., in the Georgia gubernatorial primary, is pushing the baseless allegation that Perdue lost to Gov.
Robinson is currently employed by Lindell-TV, the online streaming platform founded by MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell, one of Trump's most vocal election deniers.
In Georgia, Perdue's loss isn't only the setback in Trump's crusade to install MAGA-friendly candidates in the upper echelons of state governments.
In her 2020 House races, Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., beat her Democratic general opponent with about 50% more of the vote.
In the article, Robinson casts doubt over Kemp's margin of victory, suggesting that his win was a sign of "obvious fraud."
In the last presidential election, Trump likewise trounced Biden in Wyoming with over 70% of the vote.
According to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Trump was reportedly "stunned" by Hice's loss.
Raffensperger won 52% of the vote, while 33% went to Hice, who conceded in short order.
Robinson was fired last year after spreading misinformation about the COVID-19 vaccine.
